org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.tests.memorydb

Class MemoryDbManager

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.derbyTesting.functionTests.tests.memorydb.MemoryDbManager

  • public class MemoryDbManager
extends java.lang.Object
    Collection of convenience methods for dealing with in-memory databases. The class will keep track of databases, connections and statements created through its methods, and will delete / close these when the clean up method is invoked. This is very much the same as what BaseJDBCTestCase does, with the exception of deleting the databases.

    Note: It may be possible to integrate this functionality into the existing JUnit framework, for instance if you want to run the entire test suite with the in-memory back end.

      • getConnection

        public java.sql.Connection getConnection(java.lang.String dbNameAndAttributes)
                                  throws java.sql.SQLException
        Creates a new connection to the specified database (url).

        Note that the specified URL will be appended to a fixed JDBC protcol prefix.

        Parameters:
        dbNameAndAttributes - database name and any JDBC url attributes
        Returns:
        A connection to the specified database.
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - if connecting to the database fails

      • createStatement

        public java.sql.Statement createStatement(java.sql.Connection con)
                                   throws java.sql.SQLException
        Creates a new statement from the given connection and keeps track of it and closes it when the clean up is invoked.
        Parameters:
        con - the connection to use for creation
        Returns:
        A new statement.
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - if creating the statement fails
        See Also:
        cleanUp()

      • dropDatabase

        public void dropDatabase(java.lang.String dbNameAndAttributes)
                  throws java.sql.SQLException
        Drops the specified database.

        Note that the specified URL will be appended to a fixed JDBC protcol prefix.

        Parameters:
        dbNameAndAttributes - the database name and any attributes required to access the database (excluding the delete attribute, which is added by this method)
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - if deleting the database fails

      • createDatabase

        public java.sql.Connection createDatabase(java.lang.String dbName)
                                   throws java.sql.SQLException
        Creates a new database and keeps track of it to delete it when the clean up is invoked.

        If the database already exists, a connection to the existing database is returned.

        Parameters:
        dbName - the database name
        Returns:
        A connection to the database.
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - if creating or connecting to the database fails

      • createDatabase

        public java.sql.Connection createDatabase(java.lang.String dbName,
                                          java.lang.String dbAttributes,
                                          java.lang.String user,
                                          java.lang.String password)
                                   throws java.sql.SQLException
        Creates a new database and keeps track of it to delete it when the clean up is invoked.

        If the database already exists, a connection to the existing database is returned.

        Parameters:
        dbName - the database name
        dbAttributes - database attributes (i.e. encryption)
        user - user name
        password - user password
        Returns:
        A connection to the database.
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException - if creating or connecting to the database fails

      • cleanUp

        public void cleanUp()
             throws java.sql.SQLException
        Cleans up database resources by closing known statements and connection, and deleting known in-memory databases.
        Throws:
        java.sql.SQLException
